learning_obj.text: Identify forces that support or hinder a change
Analyze the strength of each force to understand what is helping or blocking progress
Visually map a change situation to make the dynamics easy for teams to understand
Develop targeted action plans based on the most influential forces

characteristics.text: Visual diagram showing opposing forces acting against or for a change
Focuses on balancing the forces instead of just one force
Helps identify leverage points where small actions can reduce barriers or increase support
Often used in change management and strategic planning
Simple to learn and highly flexible, can be applied to nearly any change situation (managing people, introducing new software, working out a new policy)

sub_bullets.text: Write a simple statement of the proposed change or goal
In the center, write the change goal
On the left, label: Driving Forces (for change)
On the right, label: Restraining Forces (against change)
List driving and restraining forces on each side of the change goal

process.text: Rate the strength of each force

sub_bullets.text: For each force, give a score, typically 1–5
1 = weak influence
5 = very strong influence
You can write the number next to each item or draw arrows with lengths representing the strength
Add up the total driving and total restraining strength
Look for:
Which restraining forces are strongest?
Which driving forces are weak but could be strengthened?
Are there forces you can directly influence (e.g., training, communication) vs. those you can’t (e.g., national regulations)?

process.text: Plan actions to shift the balance

sub_bullets.text: Reduce restraining forces
Provide training, extra support, pilot programs
Adjust timelines or expectations
Clarify communication and address fears
Increase driving forces
Secure leadership support
Share data on benefits
Align the change with incentives or performance goals
Imagine you implement your actions and re-rate the forces
Check if the driving total now clearly exceeds the restraining total

process.text: Decide whether and how to proceed

sub_bullets.text: Go ahead now
Delay and strengthen conditions
Do not proceed (if restraining forces remain too strong)

benefits.text: Simple and visual, easy to understand even for non-technical people
Focuses on what you can influence so you can target actions where they matter most
Supports better change planning since you don’t decide without a realistic path to success
Flexible (works for organizational change, process changes, community projects, personal goals, etc.)
Can focus on Worthwhile Development by giving an opportunity to include a driving or restricting force related to ethical well-being of others or environmental impacts

drawbacks.text: Subjective ratings (1–5) depend on people’s perceptions and biases
Can oversimplify reality and complex systems may not fit neatly into “for vs. against”
Guides thinking but doesn’t replace detailed analysis (e.g., cost–benefit, Monte Carlo, etc.)
Can be politically sensitive (listing restraining forces may point to specific departments or people)

sub_bullets.text: Proposed change: Implement a telehealth service (video and phone consultations) so rural patients can access care without travelling long distances.
In the middle
Implement telehealth service in 12 months
On the left
Driving forces (for the change)
On the right
Restraining forces (against the change)
Driving forces (for telehealth)
Patients spend hours travelling (need easier access)
Donor interest in digital health innovation
Doctors want flexibility for follow-up visits
Potential to see more patients per day
Better continuity of care for chronic patients
Restraining forces (against telehealth)
Poor internet connectivity in some villages
Staff lack digital/IT skills
Upfront cost of equipment and software
Some patients prefer in-person contact / low digital literacy
Data privacy and security concerns

example.text: Rate the strength of each force (1-5)

sub_bullets.text: Driving forces
Patients spend hours travelling 5
Donor interest in digital health 4
Doctors want flexibility 3
Potential to see more patients per day 3
Better continuity for chronic patients 4
Restraining forces
Poor internet connectivity 4
Staff lack digital skills 3
Upfront cost of equipment/software 4
Patient preference/inexperience 3
Data privacy/security concerns 3
Total driving strength: 5 + 4 + 3 + 3 + 4 = 19
Total restraining strength: 4 + 3 + 4 + 3 + 3 = 17
Telehealth might be feasible, but only if you directly address the big restraining forces
Strongest driver is travel burden on patients; strongest restrainer is poor internet connectivity and upfront cost

example.text: Plan actions to reduce restraining forces and/or boost driving forces

sub_bullets.text: Poor internet (4)
Partner with a telecom provider for stronger connection at the clinic
Create local telehealth hubs in villages with better connectivity
Use phone-only consultations where video isn’t possible
Upfront cost (4)
Start with a small pilot (one room, one doctor) before scaling
Use open-source or low-cost telehealth platforms initially
Staff lack digital skills (3)
Run training workshops, starting with a small group
Assign a master nurse/doctor to help others
Provide simple step-by-steps and cheat sheets
Patient preference/digital literacy (3)
Start with follow-up visits for patients who already know the doctor
Use community health workers to help patients connect
Explain telehealth as extra, not replacing in-person completely
Privacy/security concerns (3)
Choose a platform with strong encryption and compliance
Create clear privacy guidelines and consent forms
Train staff on how to avoid privacy breaches
New restraining forces
Poor internet: 4 → 2
Upfront cost: 4 → 2
Staff skills: 3 → 2
Patient preference: 3 → 2
Privacy concerns: 3 → 2
New restraining total: 2 + 2 + 2 + 2 + 2 = 10
Proceed with a phased telehealth implementation, starting with a one-year pilot in the main clinic plus 2–3 village hubs
After planned actions, driving forces strongly outweigh restraining ones
Major barriers (internet and cost) have realistic mitigation options
Benefits to patients (travel time, continuity) and donors (innovation) are high
Next steps
Draft a proposal for donors including force field summary and mitigation plan/pilot scope
Line up telecom partner and training schedule
Define success metrics (number of telehealth visits, patient satisfaction, travel time saved)

evaluation.text: Can you come up with at least 3 driving forces and 3 restraining forces?
Can you determine which restraining force has the highest weight?
Can you make a decision to realistically reduce the heaviest restraining force?
Can you do something to boost a driving force?
